title.narrative: Forsvarsministeriet - RO-RO-skibet til støtte for FN's Ebola indsats

description.narrative:
The aim of the project was for Denmark to offer one RORO (Roll-on Roll-off) vessel for the disposition of the UN for transportation of necessary and needed equipment for the campaign against Ebola in West Africa (UNMEER).
The original project and calculations were based on sailing of one RORO with cargo from Accra, Ghana to other ports in West Africa (Conakry, Freetown and Monrovia) with no information of cargo type and size and FIOS terms was accepted by UN.
At a later stage, UN asked for the possibility to load cargo from Port of Sudan and possible further cargo from Israel and Brindisi, Italy and the transport was planned to include discharging in Cameroun. This cargo consisted of both vehicles for UNMEER and 244 prefabs for the UN¿s mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA).
During the planning phase, Denmark entered into a dialogue with the UK for additional cargo for the Ebola-struck areas in West Africa based on a request from the UK. The first sailing schedule when BRITANNIA SEAWAYS was activated on October 16th 2014 was as follows:
2014: 26. October Departure Immingham, UK 27. October Rotterdam Bunkring 1. November Gibraltar Passage of Strait 9. November Port Sudan 15. November Brindisi 20. November Las Palmas Bunkering, crew change 24. November Conakry, Guinea 25. November Freetown, SL 26. November Monrovia, Liberia 30. November Doula, Cameroun 13. December Esbjerg
Further to this, the cargo for MINUSCA was diverted to Accra, Ghana instead of Douala, Cameroun. As the vessel was offered for UNMEER and UN declined to obtain the additional costs for the diversion to Accr
